subject: RE: [junit] Digest Number 1403
msgSnippet: Follow the directions at the bottom of every email you receive from this list.  In particular, see the section that says: To unsubscribe from this group, send
messageBody:
Follow the directions at the bottom of every
email you receive from this list. In particular,
see the section that says:

To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
junit-unsubscribe@yahoogroups.com


Todd.

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Amit Gandhi [mailto:amit_4@...]
> Sent: Tuesday, January 18, 2005 1:31 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] Digest Number 1403
>
>
> How can I unsubscribe this?
>
> Amit Gandhi
> --- junit@yahoogroups.com wrote:
>

> ______________________________________________________________
> __________
> >
> ______________________________________________________________
> __________
> >
> > Message: 1
> > Date: Mon, 17 Jan 2005 15:34:13 -0500
> > From: "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...>
> > Subject: Re: Re: Junit Test Selections for
> > testfunc()
> >
> > love wrote:
> > >
> > > I tried doing this, but it executed only the last
> > one.:myruntests
> > > [1]); 4 times::
> > > Why is it so???
> >
> > Each test is a different object, but you added the same
> object (test)
> > three times. Only the last test executes because you did this:
> >
> > create test
> > change its name to A, then add it to the list change its name to B,
> > then add it to the list again change its name to C, then
> add it to the
> > list a third time
> >
> > At the end, you have /the same test/ in the list three times, and
> > they're all named C (in your case, "test1").
> >
> > So each test has to be a separate object.
> >
> > suite.addTest(createMyTest("test7"));
> > suite.addTest(createMyTest("test3"));
> > suite.addTest(createMyTest("test1"));
> >
> > public Test createMyTest(String name) {
> > MyTest test = new MyTest();
> > test.setName(name);
> > return test;
> > }
> >
> > Or add this constructor to MyTest:
> >
> > public MyTest(String name) {
> > setName(name);
> > }
> >
> > Now:
> >
> > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test7"));
> > ...
> >
> > Either way, the three tests are different objects, so they
> can execute
> > different test methods.
> >
> > I hope this helps.
> > --
> > J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
> > Diaspar Software Services
> > http://www.diasparsoftware.com
> > Author, JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
> >
> >
> >
> ______________________________________________________________
> __________

> ______________________________________________________________
> __________

> > Subject: Testing Session Components
> >
> >
> >
> > I would like to test a shopping cart that resides in
> > the session. Is
> > there a way to keep session scoped data between
> > cacatus test? Or
> > should I setup my shopping cart for each test with
> > the appropriate data?
> >
> > Thanks,
> >
> > Matt Wright
> >
> > PS I am using ATG if that helps.

> > Message: 4
> > Date: Tue, 18 Jan 2005 10:46:26 -0500
> > From: Jason Rogers <jacaetevha@...>
> > Subject: Re: using JUnit for the existing project
> >
> > On Tuesday 18 January 2005 04:14, manjula_g_2001
> > wrote:
> > > Hello,
> > >
> > >
> > > Â  Can any body tell me,how can i use the junit to
> > test my project
> > > which already has so many classes in it.
> >
> > Start writing tests...
> >
> > Seriously, there are several approaches to testing
> > code that is already
> > written. One popular approach is to start by
> > writing a test that exposes a
> > known bug then fix your code to make the test pass.
> >
> > You could Google for "test legacy code". One of the
> > hits I got there was a
> > good page on Ward's WIKI at
> > http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?UnitTestingLegacyCode.
> >
> > --
> > Jason Rogers
> >
> > "I am crucified with Christ: nevertheless I live;
> > yet not I,
> > but Christ liveth in me: and the life which I now
> > live in
> > the flesh I live by the faith of the Son of God, who
> > loved
> > me, and gave himself for me."
> > Galatians 2:20
